awd_titl_txt: Catalyst and Methodology Development for the Synthesis of Highly Tunable Polyolefins
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers are among the most important building materials in the modern world. One class of polymer, polyolefins, comprises the largest fraction of industrial polymers. Despite their importance, polyolefins have some limitations that prevent even broader use. One of these limitations is the difficulty in expanding their physical and chemical properties beyond what is now known. For example, the introduction of chemical functionality will improve compatibility with other materials. In this project, Dr. Damien Guironnet of the University of Illinois is developing new catalytic strategies to enable the introduction of tunable, functional chemical groups within the polyolefin structure. Dr. Guironnet is actively engaging in outreach activities that build upon his research to promote student engagement in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. In particular, Dr. Guironnet is leading Chemical Engineering Department interactions with the St. Elmo Brady STEM Academy in Champaign, IL. This activity is improving the education of underrepresented primary school students and encouraging their interest in STEM careers.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Guironnet of the University of Illinois at Urbana - Champaign is developing a synthetic strategy to enhance the chemical tunability of polyolefins. The technical approach being investigated consists of performing a chain transfer polymerization technique using late transition metal catalysts and silane as chain transfer agents. The transformative aspect of this research is the ability to incorporate almost any molecule at the end of any polyolefin. The establishment of this strategy is paired with in-depth mechanistic studies of the chain transfer polymerization mechanisms. The undergraduate and graduate students involved with the project are gaining expertise in polymer science, catalysis and inorganic chemistry. This broad set of skills provides a unique training with great career opportunities. Dr. Guironnet is actively engaged in STEM outreach programs focused on the recruitment of African American boys in regional rural primary schools into the STEM fields in support of the broader impacts of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The funding of this project by the NSF has enabled multiple transformative scientific innovations related to catalytic olefin polymerization. To put our innovations in perspective, the catalytic polymerization of olefins represents more than a third of worldwide plastic production.

In the first part of our project, we developed a chain transfer polymerization method for the synthesis of semi-telechelic polyethylene. Our approach consists of using a silane as a chain transfer agent. By implementing a polymerization catalyst known to be living (no termination or chain transfer), we ensured that all the polymer chains were terminated with a functional group. Any silane could be used to functionalize the polyethylene.

In the second part of our project, we investigated the ring opening metathesis polymerization of norbornenyl monomers with Grubbs’ third generation (G3) catalyst. This polymerization method combines the fine precision of anionic polymerization and the versatility of controlled radical polymerization. The G3 catalyst is the preferred catalyst for its fast initiation and polymerization rates. We investigated the reaction mechanism for the ROMP of norbornenyl monomer initiated by G3. Through a combination of isotope labelled experiments and DFT calculations, we identified the rate-determining step of the polymerization mechanism which allowed us to derive the rate law for the polymerization. We also investigated the root cause for the difference in reactivity between endo and exo monomers and the impact of functional groups.

In the third and last part of this project, we investigated the catalytic copolymerization of ethylene and carbon monoxide. The copolymer obtained from this reaction is known to be photodegradable. Our goal was to synthesize a polymer that contains very low amount of CO. Low incorporations of CO would simultaneously maintain the processability of the polyethylene while also providing some photodegradability.  The technical challenge we faced, however, is that CO is a very reactive monomer and thus most catalysts yield alternated copolymers. We have identified a palladium catalyst that can yield low CO incorporation copolymers when very small CO/ethylene feed ratios are implemented. We attempted to determine the copolymerization parameters for this catalyst but our current set-up as well as the high CO sensitivity of the catalyst prevented us from accurately determining  the monomer feed composition.

 

Broader impact. This grant supported the graduate work of 2 students. Both found an industrial job before graduation.

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2022
Modified by: Damien Guironnet

In the first part of our project, we developed a chain transfer polymerization method for the synthesis of semi-telechelic polyethylene. In the second part of our project, we investigated the ring opening metathesis polymerization of norbornenyl monomers with Grubbs’ third generation (G3) catalyst. Through a combination of isotope labelled experiments and DFT calculations, we identified the rate-determining step of the polymerization mechanism which allowed us to derive the rate law for the polymerization. In the third and last part of this project, we investigated the catalytic copolymerization of ethylene and carbon monoxide. The copolymer obtained from this reaction is known to be photodegradable. Low incorporations of CO would simultaneously maintain the processability of the polyethylene while also providing some photodegradability. We attempted to determine the copolymerization parameters for this catalyst but our current set-up as well as the high CO sensitivity of the catalyst prevented us from accurately determining  the monomer feed composition.
